content:
I am a first-year Computer Science MS student at Stanford University. My research interests are in the areas of systems, machine learning and high-performance computing. I am currently involved in research at the Future Data Systems Lab led by Prof. Matei Zaharia and the Hazy Research Lab led by Prof. Chris Re.
Prior to Stanford, I completed my undergrad at the Indian Institue of Technology Kanpur where I majored in Electrical Engineering At IIT Kanpur, I worked with Prof. Preeti Malakar. I also spent a summer working with Prof. Denis Trystram at DataMove, INRIA.
summary: I am a first-year Computer Science MS student at Stanford University. My research interests are in the areas of systems, machine learning and high-performance computing. I am currently involved in research at the Future Data Systems Lab led by Prof.
title: Priya Mishra

content: I recently started working with Dr. Fiodar Kazhamiaka in the Future Data Systems Lab, led by Prof. Matei Zaharia on removing sampling bias in data collected from autonomous vehicles. For more info, check out their position paper.
summary: I recently started working with Dr. Fiodar Kazhamiaka in the Future Data Systems Lab, led by Prof. Matei Zaharia on removing sampling bias in data collected from autonomous vehicles. For more info, check out their position paper.
title: De-biasing Autonomous Vehicle Data

content: I am currently working in the Hazy Research Lab led by Prof. Chris Re on the Meerkat project. Meerkat is a new data library for machine learning datasets that allows easier interaction with data across various modalities. I implemented an ML module to integrate Meerkat with PyTorch, Lightning and Huggingface models. The module offers functionalities.
summary: I am currently working in the Hazy Research Lab led by Prof. Chris Re on the Meerkat project. Meerkat is a new data library for machine learning datasets that allows easier interaction with data across various modalities.
title: Meerkat: DataPanels for Machine Learning

summary: Job schedulers play an important role in selecting optimal resources for the submitted jobs. However, most of the current job schedulers do not consider job-specific characteristics such as communication patterns during resource allocation. This often leads to sub-optimal node allocations. We propose three node allocation algorithms that consider the jobâ€™s communication behavior to improve the performance of communication-intensive jobs. We develop our algorithms for tree-based network topologies. The proposed algorithms aim at minimizing network contention by allocating nodes on the least contended switches. We also show that allocating nodes in powers of two leads to a decrease in inter-switch communication for MPI communications, which further improves performance. We implement and evaluate our algorithms using SLURM, a widely-used and well-known job scheduler. We show that the proposed algorithms can reduce the execution times of communication-intensive jobs by 9% (326 hours) on average. The average wait time of jobs is reducedby 31% across three supercomputer job logs.
title: Communication-aware Job Scheduling using SLURM

content: In this work, we collaborated with Qarnot, a green cloud computing company, to design an energy disaggregation algorithm for their smart buildings. The Qarnot Computing platform uses computing-heaters and utilizes the waste heat from IT computations in their buidings and offices. Through energy disaggregation, our aim was to better understand the energy requirements at different locations of the building and hence, forecast energy needs. Using this information, we can achieve a more efficient job scheduling, for example, scheduling more jobs where there is greater energy requirement. We developed an integer linear programming approach using the information provided by Qarnot Computing about different devices used in their offices and buildings.
summary: In this work, we collaborated with Qarnot, a green cloud computing company, to design an energy disaggregation algorithm for their smart buildings. The Qarnot Computing platform uses computing-heaters and utilizes the waste heat from IT computations in their buidings and offices.
title: Energy Disaggregation

content: In this work, we were interested in studying the impact of job runtime estimates on the performance of non-clairoyant scheduling algorithms. More specifically, we consider the problem of scheduling a set of independent jobs whose processing times are unknown. User runtimes are known to be highly inaccurate. Scheduling policies such as backfilling or shortest job first rely on these estimates to schedule jobs. In this work, we explore the use of machine learning methods to provide better estimates for the exceution times using user history and job characteristics. Instead of estimating the exact value of the job runtime, we consider that the jobs fall in two categories – short and long jobs and predict the type of each job. We used several classification models as well as simpler schemes such as predicting based on the class of previously submitted jobs alone. We evaluated our models using several full workload traces.
summary: In this work, we were interested in studying the impact of job runtime estimates on the performance of non-clairoyant scheduling algorithms. More specifically, we consider the problem of scheduling a set of independent jobs whose processing times are unknown.
title: Improving Scheduling using Job Runtime Predictions

content:
Jobs submitted to clusters or supercomputers vary in resource requirements and execution times. Increasingly, they also vary in other characteristics such as communication and I/O behavior. Most of the current job-schedulers do not consider the communication characteristics of a job which leads to sub-optimal allocations.
We implemented three new node-allocation algorithms, greedy, balanced and adaptive[^1]. We proposed a novel way of optimizing node-allocation based on underlying algorithms of MPI collectives.
The balanced algorithm aims at allocating nodes in powers of two on These algorithms were implemented using SLURM. The two algorithms reduce execution time by 12% and wait times by 53% on average as compared to the default SLURM algorithm.
Additional details can be found in the paper: Communication-aware Job Scheduling using SLURM
summary: Jobs submitted to clusters or supercomputers vary in resource requirements and execution times. Increasingly, they also vary in other characteristics such as communication and I/O behavior. Most of the current job-schedulers do not consider the communication characteristics of a job which leads to sub-optimal allocations.
title: Communication-aware Job Scheduling using SLURM
